When the big theme park opened up in town nobody thought that it would be the biggest disaster to ever befall mankind. Algernon, the disease that warps the body or mind to suit its own desire (in the process killing the host spiritually), has infected everyone there.
Keita, at the time, is asleep having a dream. There's a girl in a very torn-up suit. She is saying something but he can't tell what. He looks down and he is also in a torn up suit. Then his alarm clock wakes him up. When he goes to school that day his class gets a new student, Hinoki, the girl from his dreams who is also his childhood friend.
Eventually, Keita gets to help pilot the Kakusajin, a machine that can deliver a very devastating attack called the Synapse Attack (for those of you wondering a Synapse is what the electrical charges between cells and nerves are called). Basically, the Synapse Attack is a fluid that attacks the nerve and cell receptors and their senders and literally destroys the cells.
However, the creature they are fighting is hardly effected by it, and knocks them down. But before it land the final blow, 
, called 
 by the Akamatsu team, falls from above in a very fallen angel like pose. As he lands, he eats the seed of Nebula, a seed coming from the Animus which grows on humans when they die in a specific way.
Changing into the awesomely powerful dragon-like 
, he easily destroys the creature with the Psycho Voice, an attack that ruptures the cells in the body and makes them fall apart. And that's just the first episode...

is an angel who came from the future, to prevent the creation of a machine which caused eternal youth. The person who creates this machine is Junior-high student Sakura Kusakabe.
Originally, 
 was sent from the future to kill Sakura-kun, but instead has become quite attached to him. She wields a spiked metal bat ("Excaliborg") and frequently kills Sakura accidentally.

Black Blood Brothers takes place in a world where people are divided into the "Red Bloods" (Humans), "Black Bloods" (Vampires), and "Old Bloods" (Ancient Vampires). The series takes place ten years after a Holy War raged in Hong Kong. Mochitsuki Jurou, also known as the Silver Blade, was a lone and legendary war hero who defeated the sinister Kowloon Children during the Holy War, but victory came at the cost of the life of his lover.
Deciding to return home to Japan to his brother, Mochitsuki Kotaro, the brothers (who are both Old Bloods and descendants of an elite group of vampires) soon learn the Kowloon Children weren't out for the count just yet. The surviving Kowloon members are seeking a portal to a "Special Zone", which is a secret civilization where the Kowloon Children are not allowed to reach. But the Kowloon make the battle a personal one when they kidnap Kotaro, causing Jurou to fight them once again.

Yukio Tanaka, known as Koyuki, is your average and boring 14 year old Japanese youth. His life is nothing to be proud of. He seems to have the worst luck with girls, and his existence seems pretty unexciting. Koyuki seriously wants to escape adolescence and make his life better. Rock was something Tanaka had never given thought to. In fact, he has a rather poor knowledge of music. But when he was reunited with his friend from middle school, Izumi Ishiguro, everything unfolds. He starts listening to Dying Breed, and Maho-san (his crush) soon finds his talent for singing.
Koyuki's luck then changes one day when he helps out a strange and mismatched Frankenstein-like dog named 
 who was being teased by some bullies. Turns out that the dog is owned by a fairly well-known guitarist named Ryuusuke Minami. Initially, Ryuusuke's original opinion of Koyuki was very low, but eventually, after discovering that Koyuki can sing, Ryuusuke invites Koyuki to join his up-and-coming band, which gets named after his dog, 
. Koyuki soon discovers his talent and his life finally takes the exciting turn he's been yearning for.
Thus begins the rough and surprising journey of BECK, to rise to the top of the charts and into stardom itself! Watch as the band progresses through all of their stages toward stardom.

As if life wasn't hard enough, it seems that in the Beet universe the Earth has become overrun with monsters known as Vandels who love nothing better than to terrorize good, innocent folk. Thankfully, a group of five warriors (known as Vandel Busters) called the Zenon Warriors are there to protect the hometown of Beet, our main character. I'm not sure what all of the other towns do... or maybe they just don't matter. At any rate, Beet is a young boy that dreams of becoming a Vandel Buster, yet the Zenon Warriors always shut him down, saying he's just a kid... which he is. But he's drinking his milk, eating his vegetables, and working out on his Ab-lounger, as he's bound and determined to fight monsters for a living, and "end this century of darkness".
So everything is all hunky-dory until one day a powerful Vandel comes knocking on the town's door... and as typical the Zenon Warriors answer. But this time, Beet shows up to watch, and ends up getting mortally wounded. Dumb kid. Now the five Vandel Busters must give up their life force energy in order for Beet to survive. Way to go kid... see what happens when you don't listen? But now Beet not only has the power of five powerful warriors inside him, he has the drive and determination to use that power to rid the Earth of Vandels so that no one else will have to suffer because of them. Okay, but first he needs to practice a bit....

Three years later, nobody has seen or heard from Beet. Beet's childhood friend (and possible future wife), Paola, has grown into a Vandel Buster and protects the village. But then a 2-star Vandel called Mugine of the Black Bog starts making life miserable for the townsfolk. Although Paola doesn't quite have what it takes to face off against a 2-star Vandel, she goes for it anyway. I know it's hard to just sit by and not do anything, but c'mon here, who is gonna protect the village if you go and get yourself killed, young lady!? Thankfully, after three years of being off training, Beet decides to come back, and helps her out of the jam. Despite being a lower level Vandel Buster than Paola, Beet makes mincemeat out of the baddies like they were nothing but pesky insects.
The artwork and animation seems pretty good for a TV show. There were a lot of scenes with cool poses and lighting that I thought would make for some cool posters or wall scrolls or desktop wallpapers. I checked out the 
 website but they didn't seem to have any wallpapers available yet. Hopefully that will be coming soon.
The first DVD release, 
, contains the first four episodes in the series (
, 
, 
, and 
), presented in both English and Japanese with optional subtitles. While the English dubbing for some of the characters is pretty good, for other characters it just sounds more like someone trying to do a voice rather than an actual, real voice. Mostly I noticed this about the smaller roles, such as random townsfolk. It kind of reminded me of the old 
 series. But I also do understand it, as it's not like TV shows have an unlimited budget to work with (although this was released on DVD, it was clearly produced as a TV series). I'm just really glad they were able to include the original Japanese dialog track on the DVD. And both my wife and I are really looking forward to viewing more episodes as to see where this story is going.
Illumitoon Entertainment, Ltd. announced that based on overwhelming demand it will be initiating a trade-in program for its "dubtitled" DVDs. "Dubtitles" are video with the English dialogue superimposed over Japanese audio, as opposed to true Japanese translations of the Japanese audio.
"It's something that's obviously very important to the fans, and we want to give them what they want," said Barry Watson, President/CEO of Illumitoon. "Going forward we want to incorporate literal translations on all our anime product."
The trade-in program is only available through Illumitoon's website, and will not be available through retailers. Details are available at 
. The trade-in offer applies to all Illumitoon DVDs released before April 30, 2007, specifically:
BoBoBo-Bo BoBoBo - Bo-nafide Protector of Hair

Beet the Vandel Buster - The Sacrifice

B't X - Empire of the Machines
"We're always listening to our fans, and are extremely grateful for their input," said Watson. "I think fans will be very pleased."
Illumitoon is offering the trade-in program through 5/30/2007. For more information, visit the company's website at 
.

Notice: 
 is not Japanese animation! It is a cartoon produced in the US. However, it was animated and shown in Japan, and also spawned various anime sequels, updates, and spinoffs, therefore I have decided to include it on this site. If you're one of those hard-core anime purists who can't stand seeing a non-anime series on a site dedicated to Japanese Animation, then just press the Back button on your web browser and pretend like you were never here.
Beast Machines is the sequel to the 
 series, and takes place where the last series left off. After finally defeating Megatron on Earth, the Maximals left home for Cybertron, however their victory would be a short lived one. When they finally make it home to Cybertron, they discovered that their home has changed dramatically. They soon find out that things have taken a turn for the worst.
Megatron has completely taken over Cybertron! To make matters worse, many of the Maximals are mysteriously missing, leaving only Primal, Cheetor, Rattrap and Black Arachnia to fend for themselves. However, they become reformatted into new techno-organic forms by the Oracle and learn new methods of transforming in order to defeat their enemies.
But they go into a battle where they're seriously outnumbered. Megatron has developed his own mass army known as the Vehicons in order to enforce his rule. However, Primal and company discover new allies and old ones as well. As they unravel the truth behind Megatron's apparent takeover, the battle for Cybertron will dramatically change their world in ways they can't imagine.
Editor's Note: You can also check out 
.

related.name: Transformers the Movie: Mokushiroku Matrix yo Eien ni
Tatakae! Chou Robot Seimei Tai Transformers Victory

description:
Belle and Sebastian was made in 1981, and premiered on Nickelodeon in June, 1984. It aired on Nick until 1990. It aired in the early morning.
The story was about a young boy named Sebastian, and a large white Great Pyrenee dog named Belle. Sebastian had been raised by an old man named Cecil and had never seen his mother. His mother had given birth to him after Cecil rescued him, and had left, promising to return someday. She was a gypsy lady and also worked for a traveling carnival.
Belle was a large white dog who lived in the mountains, and was believed to be evil. In reality Belle was gentle, but only Sebastian knew it. He had apparently been blamed for some bad things that had happened in the town that Sebastian lived in, which was located near the Pyrenes Mountains of France. It is through these mountains that Belle and Sebastian have all their great adventures.
Sebastian is about 11 or 12 or so, and begins to wonder what happened to his mother. Cecil tells him about her, and he decides to go and look for her. At first Marie, who is his aunt (?) will not allow it, but eventually he leaves anyway with Belle and a small dog he carries in his pocket named Poochie. They travel all over the Mountains, and nearly find his mother on several occasions. They are pursued by a Lieutenant (or Inspector) Garcia, who wants to capture Belle. They also encounter a girl named Sara, who makes two appearances in the story.
Eventually Sebastian finds his mother who I believe was in a cave near where the story had started. Her name was Isobelle. She states that Sebastian's father had been a French (?) painter, and she had broken gypsy code by marrying outside the culture. She also says that Sebastian's father died before he was born.
Isobelle was very sick, however, so Sebastian needed to find a doctor badly. He ties a letter explaining the situation around Belle's neck and sends him to the village for help. Marie is engaged to the doctor who comes to Isobelle's aid, and Isobelle recovers. This action by Belle proves to everyone he was not the "White Monster" (as they called him).
After being reunited with his mother, Sebastian receives a visit from his friend Sarah and her father. It turns out that Sarah's father had actually known Isabel in the past. It looked like Isabel and Sara's father were gonna hook up (which I always thought was weird because I sensed a romantic thing going on with Sebastian and Sara and that would create some weird thing with their respective parents becoming a couple or getting married).
On the final episode Marie marries the doctor, and Cecil, Isobelle, Sebastian, Belle, and Poochie all live happily together.

is finally out of the hospital, and the entire gang (
, 
, 
) is invited to his victory party for getting back in the ring. While there, they are confronted by Sulia, a poor young girl who needs serious help.
Sulia's brother, 
, has found 3 peices of an ancient artifact known as the Armor Of Mars. The legend says that if one person were to collect all six peices of the armor, then that person would become a god. So, of course, 
 and company decide to help Sulia locate some of the armor's pieces before Laucorn. Unfortunately, they don't succeed, and Laucorn obtains all the armor pieces. This is, in part, thanks to Laucorn's three element-controlling henchmen, 
 (who controls the wind), 
 (who controls the water), and Jamin (who controls fire and has variations of all of 
's moves)
During the search, 
 becomes enamored with Sulia, despite his own objections to her advances. When Laucorn transcends mortality, a final battle takes place but Laucorn proves too powerful for any of the fighters. Sulia sacrifices her own life to stop Laucorn, but when he dies Mars, the actual god of war, appears to reclaim his armor. Nothing 
 can't handle. 
 defeats the god of war, and they all escape just in time to watch the fireworks.

Note: 
 is NOT Japanese Animation, though it has been broadcasted in Japan, and also spawned a few anime spinoffs that have yet to be released in the U.S. Therefore, I have decided to include it on this site. (It is also worth noting that a lot of the English VA's on this show went on to voice characters for the more recent Transformers anime.)
Beast Wars is both a sequel and prequel to the original 
 series. Taking place three hundred years after the Great War between the Autobots and Decepticons, their descendents the Maximals and Predicons now reside in Cybertron. The Maximals (Autobot Descendents) have reigned as the main power of Cybertron and have created co-existance between the Predicons (Decepticon descendents).
However, one Predicon known as Megatron (named in honor of the Decepticon leader) steals a Cybertronian relic known as the Golden Disk. Sent to chase Megatron and the Predicons is Optimus Primal and his band of Maximals. After chasing down the Predicons, both teams of Transformers mysteriously land on a planet (which is later revealed to be Prehistoric Earth).
Trapped on the planet, the Beast Wars begin between the two factions. However, Megatron's ambitions grow bigger by the day, and the Beast Wars will soon erupt into a battle that could place the history of Cybertron and the fate of the entire universe at stake....

title: Fatal Fury: Legend of the Hungry Wolf

description:
Fatal Fury: Legend of the Hungry Wolf is about 
 and 
. The story starts when they are children and their father, Jeff Bogard, gets killed by Geese Howard. This prompts the Bogard brothers to go off and train so that they may achieve enough skill to defeat the man who killed their father.
Ten years later they return. While looking for Geese Howard, 
 meets Lily in a bar. A fight soon ensues, and 
 ends up beating everyone in the bar. 
 then comes to challenge 
 to a fight. 
 accepts. It doesn't last long as the cops move in to break it up. The two men make a run for it. 
 says he knows 
's younger brother, 
. They both decide to join the King of Fighters tornament. The next day, 
 meets 
 at the graveyard where the two start to battle. Only minutes into the fight, their master (Master Tan) breaks it up. He tells them that he will teach a secert techinque to only the best fighter. They will need this techinque to defeat Geese.
When the King of Fighter's tornament starts, Lily is sent by Geese to kill 
 with a poisioned bottle of wine. She is unable to go through with it, and they end up falling in love instead. 
, 
, and 
 all beat their respective opponents, when finally the match is set for 
 and 
 to fight. What they don't know is that Geese has hired assassins to kill the Bogard brothers so that they don't learn the secert techinque that Master Tan will teach one of them. As the fight starts, 
 sees the assassins and jumps in front of the bullet. The assassins go for another shot, but the lights go out and the three of them vanish. Lily had shut-off the power and had tried to save them, but in doing so she, herself, got killed. Moments later they are surrounded by many men. All of a sudden Master Tan comes through the gate to rescue them. On their way out, Billy (a fighter and a worker for Geese Howard) severly injurs Master Tan.
They arrive at a hospital to treat Master Tan and 
. The doctor says Master Tan will die soon. This causes 
 to run out, with revenge soley on his mind. Master Tan awakes, and stops 
 from going after 
. Master Tan had choosen 
 to learn his secert techinque, "The Hurricane Punch", which creates a type of hurricane. After Master Tan had shown 
 how to do this techinque, he goes into a deep trance.
Meanwhile, 
 and 
 arrive at Geese's fortress, attacking all the guards. 
 kicks Billy's ass, and 
 fights a giant wrester. When 
 and 
 confront Geese, he takes them out with one shot. Then 
 arrives and swears to kill Geese. He trys his power wave and burn knuckles, but Geese knows all his moves. All but one, that is. 
 uses the Hurrican Punch. The first attempt was weak, and was stopped by Geese. The second attempt left Geese flying through the air and into the lake. In the end they all go there separate ways.

title: Battle Fighters: Garou Densetsu
Battle Fighters: Legend of the Hungry Wolf

description:
Note: Battle Athletes Victory is an alternate retelling of the OVA Series.
Battle Athletes takes place in the far future of the year 4998 (as opposed to 4999 in the OVA series) and takes place after a tumultuous period for humanity. Wars nearly devastated the entire planet (first between humanity and later against an alien race).
The war against the aliens has lasted for a long period of time, and eventually became a contest of physical strength after negotiations between both sides. Peace fell over the Earth once again when a human competitor won the historic competition.
Presently, a competition known as the "Cosmic Beauty" (held by the United Systems Sports Academy) has become all the rage around the world, and is held at the famous University Satellite. Many girls from around the world gather at this special event to compete for this prestigious title.
The story begins with Akari Kanzaki, the daughter of a past Cosmic Beauty. Hoping to follow in her mother's footsteps, she trains to compete in the games. However, the road to victory is a long and rigorous one. Will Akari live her dream and come out on top?

In 1978, countless viewers all over the world got their first look at Gatchaman as Battle of the Planets. Fans followed the adventures of G-Force, five young orphans augmented with cerebonic implants: the heroic leader 
, hot-headed 
, beautiful 
, stuttering kid-clone 
 and Space Burger-scarfing 
. Assisted by their "robot guardian," 
, G-Force flew their warship, the Phoenix, to faraway planets and battled evil armies from Planet Spectra with superpowered tricks like the "Whirlwind Pyramid" and the "Fiery Phoenix." The 70's-era fashions and phrases ("big ten", "hang loose") make the show a retro favorite today.
Of all the versions, Battle of the Planets, with its big-budget production and enthusiastic staff, hooked the most international fans. The only drawback to the show was that even the youngest viewers were able to see through certain kidvid cop-outs: All the battles on "other worlds" looked like they took place on Earth (where they actually did in Gatchaman). There were obvious differences between the original animation and the segments added in America (the "ready room" scene, shots of the Phoenix flying through space, etc.). And all those "robot planes" had suspiciously human-looking pilots.
This coverup wasn't all bad: the suspicion that there was more to Battle of the Planets made the show even more interesting. Why didn't we get to see 
 fight very much? Were there some special scenes we were missing? Why did 
 make those funny noises? Some of us kids saw past the explanation that 
 was a test tube experiment and guessed that the original character just had a lot to say, maybe some of it even naughty. (We were right!)
The professional voice cast and superb new music score made the show fun to watch and set the ultimate standard for dubbed Japanese animation. Sandy Frank put over $5 million into production of this series, and it shows. In order to reduce the amount of violence in the show, some episodes were dissected and substituted with poor-quality animation and lame excuses ("Don't worry, kids. All the injured and dying bystanders you see here are only robots." And what truly happened to 
's father, anyway?). As much as ten minutes of the program was taken up by the prattling of 
 and his friends.

Battle of the Planets was the show that started it all; the show that introduced most Western fans to Gatchaman and to Japanese animation in general. (Tezuka's 
 and 
 ran in the mid-60s and early 70s, but it was Battle of the Planets that started the anime ball rolling.) It's only too easy to villify Sandy Frank for all the cuts that were made to this show, but to be perfectly honest, Sandy Frank was only responsible for seeing potential in Gatchaman, hiring a staff to do the conversion and marketing the result. The producer Frank hired, Jameson Brewer, worked an extremely tight schedule (one episode a week) with few to no resources (no scripts, just the Japanese episodes "as is"), under heavy limitations. If you think about it, the censors are truly to blame--anyone who had to butt heads with Action for Children's Television in the mid seventies will know just how exasperating it is to put out any kind of animated entertainment. On the other hand, we have a lot to thank Sandy and his staff for. They invested a great deal of money and effort in the production of Battle of the Planets; hired professional actors (some who truly enjoyed working on the show), writers and composers, and sold this show "like the second coming." Few other animated productions (including the subsequent dubs of Gatchaman: 
 and 
) have been able to match the quality due to tighter budgets and...I don't know, lack of "the right stuff." Personally, this is my favorite dubbed version, and has accounted for many happy childhood hours in front of the TV.

In the near future, the world is menaced by a criminal organization known only as the Galactor Syndicate. Led by 
, who answers to a mysterious entity known as Overlord X, Galactor's monster mechs threathen the International Science Organization's (ISO) plans to create a pollution-free energy source. To combat the menace of Galactor, 
 decides that the time has come to bring in the ISO's secret weapon: five bird-garbed youths trained in the ways of the ninja and armed with the most remarkable weaponry science can produce. These five are the Science Ninja Team!
Led by 
 (also known as 
), a bold leader type, the team includes 
, a rebel out for revenge against Galactor, 
, communications and demolitions expert, 
, 
's adopted kid brother and just as skilled as the others, and 
, a brawny sort who not only is the pilot of the God Phoenix, he is also the only one of the five with living family.
Together, these five are the world's only hope against Galactor.

In 1991, artist and writer Yukito Kishiro began to create a new graphic series for Shueisha Publishing's "Business Jump," a weekly comic aimed at adult audiences. Entitled "Gunnm" (literally "Gun Dream"), Kishiro's continuing odyssey of a young female cyborg's journey of self-discovery, set in a unique and highly detailed fantasy setting, captured the imagination of Japanese readers. Today, over 900,000 devoted fans follow Gunnm on a weekly basis.
In 1992, 
, one of North America's premiere publishers of Japanese comic books, or manga, decided to bring 
 and her world to the English-reading public, at that time changing both the title and the main character's name to "Battle Angel Alita". Again, the response was overwhelming, as Kishiro's masterful storytelling enthralled a whole new legion of fans.
In 1993, a team of extraordinary animatora, artists, and writers began the arduous task of transforming Kishiro's intricate universe into a series of Original Animation Videos, or OAVs. The results, to date, are two of the most finely realized animated films ever created for any medium: "Gunnm - Rusty Angel" and "Gunnm - Tears Sign". 
 is very proud to present both of these extraordinary films, together, as "Battle Angel".

I don't care what the title says, Battle Skipper is a 3-part OVA series, NOT a movie. Set sometime in the future, three new students to Saint Ignacio's School for Girls must now decide which school club they would like to join. The most obvious choice would be the Debutante club, helped by president Sayka Kitaouji, as that's the club that every other new student dreams of joining. Just about everyone who gains membership eventually goes on to great status, but the line for applicants is insanely long, and very few every get accepted. But our three girls are looking at an alternative, the Etiquette Club, led by president Reika Ayanokouji along with vice-president of the club Rie Shibusawa. The Etiquette Club is the complete opposite of the Debutante club in that very few people ever even apply for membership. In fact, the current membership consists of only Reika and Rie.

The three potentials of the Etiquette club are Saori Tachibana, Shihoko Sakaki, and Kanami Izaki. Saori and Shihoko were already friends before starting at St. Ignacio's, and it's at an assembly that they both met Kanami. Earlier in the day, Shihoko became instantly infatuated with Rie during their brief encounter, so she definitely wants to join Rie's club. Saori, being Shihoko's friend, agrees to go along with her, while Kanami seems to have her own reasons for wanting the join. So together, all three enter the door to club building... only to be greeted by arrows flying right toward them. Saori and Kanami easily avoid or deflect the arrows, but unfortunately Shihoko takes one right to the forehead. Fortunately, the arrows were tipped with suction cups. Unfortunately, the arrows were a test, and Shihoko failed.

So Saori passed and made membership, even though she didn't want it, while Shihoko failed to become a member, even though she really wanted it. Anyone see a solution coming? Yep, Saori agrees to be a member if they also make Shihoko a member. Vice-president Rie objects, but president Reika accepts, and thus the extremely unpopular Etiquette club now has a total of five members. We find that this number holds some sort of significance, as Rie lets slip some comment about it, but we're not told precisely what. Ah, but don't worry there friends! You all know that we're going to be finding out really, really soon! Plus we also learn during this conversation that Kanami Izaki is actually an extremely talented young lady that could have easily been at the top and made it into the Debutante club. So why exactly did she choose this club...?

Later that evening we find our three new recruits sneaking around the building, searching for the secret of the club. They soon find it. With the touch of a hidden button, the whole room begins to change. The floor begins to move downward, taking them to a completely metallic room, with five numbered tubes set into the wall. A quick peek by Shihoko into one of the tubes activates a suction that pulls her right in, and closes it up. Unsure of what to do, Saori and Kanami each take a tube and follow her down. During the journey, their clothes are magically replaced by some kind of skin-tight uniforms. The end of the tubes spit them out into robotic vehicles called Battle Skipper Multipurpose Robot Vehicles (MRV). So it seems the secret of the club is that it's actually just a front for the Ex-Stars, a group of fine young ladies that uses extremely sophisticated robotic combat vehicles to help protect the world.

Anyway, the girls surmise that Reika and Rie are in trouble, and take off to help. At the end of the conflict, two things are clear: the new recruits definitely have the drive and desire to become full Ex-Stars, and the new recruits need a lot of training! But don't worry, if anyone can whip these recruits into shape it's Rie. The only question is can she do it in time to face off against their most powerful foes to date, a new military model MRV that packs a ton of firepower. Oh yeah, and did I mention that mastermind behind the plot to take down the Ex-Stars is none other than the president of the Debutante club, Sayka Kitaouji? Apparently she holds some kind of grudge or something. Ah, but I'm sure it'll all work out.

The Toshinden...an annual tournament to see who is the best. Set up by an entity known simply as "The Organization," the greatest fighters in the world fight for the title.
Each Toshinden fighter has reasons for fighting. Some seek answers. Others seek themselves. Outside the Toshinden tournament, they may even be friends, but once the fight begins, each will fight for his or her life, without restraints or regrets.
This time, however, events are unfolding that are bringing the fighters together. Someone is wreaking havoc and taking out each Toshinden fighter one by one. Could it be Sho, Eiji's long-lost brother? Is it a move by the Organization? Does it have anything to do with Gaia?
Based on the namesake 3-D fighting game and brought to animation by Masami Obari, renowned for his action titles, Battle Arena Toshinden is another addition to the growing number of fighting-game-based titles that include Street Fighter II V, Art of Fighting, and Fatal Fury (another by Masami Obari).

Like the Animatrix, Batman: Gotham Knight is the collaboration between DC Comics and anime industry's most famous directors and producers. This anthology is told in six short films all taking place in between "Batman Begins" and the upcoming sequel "The Dark Knight." All six stories tell of Batman's transition from tormented vigilante to the Dark Knight and the protector of the crime-riddled Gotham. Some of the topics discussed include the mythos of the Batman told by children, the race to protect his future friend James Gordon from a deadly assassin, and the physical and mental torments Bruce Wayne endures as he develops as the Batman.

Notice: 
 is not Japanese animation! It is a cartoon produced in the US. However, because it has a style that is strongly influenced by anime, I have decided to include it on this site. If you're one of those hard-core anime purists who can't stand seeing a non-anime series on a site dedicated to Japanese Animation, then just press the Back button on your web browser and pretend like you were never here.
Like a grim angel guarding the citizens of Gotham City, 
, the Dark Knight, watches over its citizens in the darkness of night, protecting them from the various criminals, terrorists, and predators who would scar their lives and ravage their existences. His own origins were born out of his personal tragedy, so he dedicates his life by preventing the same to others.
This series, which was loosely based on the 1989 Tim Burton movie and was originally first aired on FOX, focuses more on drama and action than the movie did, which profiles 
 more closely to the vision of Bob Kane's original comic book.

 is not Japanese animation! It is a cartoon produced in the US. However, because it has a style that is strongly influenced by anime, I have decided to include it on this site. If you're one of those hard-core anime purists who can't stand seeing a non-anime series on a site dedicated to Japanese Animation, then just press the Back button on your web browser and pretend like you were never here.
Ben 10 tells the fantastic story of Benjamin Tennyson, a boy who is on vacation with his cousin 
 and his grandfather Max. At the start of their summer trip, Ben is almost hit by a strange alien device. He finds out that it's an Omnitrix, which is a watch-like alien device capable of transforming anyone who possesses it into 10 different alien species, each with their own respective power/ability. From here Ben faces the responsibility of using his powers to fight evil, though Ben is still young and not very mature. However, he'll have to learn to master his abilities to fight off the onslaught of Vilgax, an evil Galactic conqueror who wants the Omnitrix back in order to begin his invasion and conquest of Earth. Does Ben have what it takes to save the world?

creator: Bob Kane
, Bruce Timm, Paul Dini, Alan Burnett
title: Batman Beyond

If you're one of those hard-core anime purists who can't stand seeing a non-anime series on a site dedicated to Japanese Animation, then just press the Back button on your web browser and pretend like you were never here.
For most of his life 
 has been fighting the battle against evil as his alter ego Batman. However, age is the only thing that could ever stop him. Finally realizing that he was growing too old for the job, he hung up his cape and cowl for good. Batman Beyond takes place in the future, after Batman the Animated Series.
 is a former teenage delinquent who steps up to take the mantle as the next Batman. After a chance encounter with 
 (and the murder of his father) he is taken under 
's wing to train as Batman. However, in the future, newer and deadlier criminals are out to cause trouble. And even a few villains from the past will come to haunt Wayne and 
.

Bastard!! takes place in a post-apocalyptic future where most of the Earth has been destroyed by a powerful being known as Ansla-Sax. Humanity has forsaken technology in favor of magic and the occult. In this new world, many forces are battling it out to find the seals that constrain the monster responsible for the world's destruction.
Dark Schneider is a powerful, but extremely reckless sorcerer. Leading a group of magicians hoping to dominate and rebuild society as a utopia, he decides to change the ways of these magicians. Together, they battle the forces of evil that are hellbent on reviving Ansla-Sax. Will this unruly bunch of Sorcerers save the day?

creator: Bob Kane
, Bruce Timm, Paul Dini, Alan Burnett
title: Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker

description:
Notice: 
 is not Japanese Animation! It is a cartoon produced in the US (though animated in Japan through TMS). However, because it has a style that is strongly influenced by anime, I have decided to include it on this site. If you're one of those hard-core anime purists who can't stand seeing a non-anime series on a site dedicated to Japanese Animation, then just press the Back button on your web browser and pretend like you were never here.
In the future, teenager 
 has taken the mantle as the new Batman while under the elderly 
's wing. However, Batman's deadliest enemy has mysteriously returned to terrorize Gotham City once again. Taking control of the Jokerz (a vicious gang taking after him) he begins his assault on the city. To make matters worse, he knows everything about 
 and his former alter ego!
Now Terry must face his biggest challenge ever as he stands against the seemingly immortal Clown Prince of Crime. But stopping him also means opening a painful chapter from 
's past, one where the Joker made his most incredibly sadistic punchline ever....
Who is this new Joker, and will Gotham fall from the return of one of its greatest enemies?

BAOH is a show about trying to create the ultimate killing machine. Scientists have found a parasite that gives awesome powers to whoever has it. Whenever BAOH gets hurt, the host mutates and it gives more and more powers and strength to the possessor according to how much damage is done.
The story revolves around two young people, a man, who is infected with the parasite, and a female child, who freed him. They are on the run from the scientists and the military who are trying to get him back. It follows their exploits and they get closer and closer to finding out the true story of BAOH.
I thought that this particular anime was pretty good. The only problem that I had with it was that whenver BAOH demonstrated a new power, it popped up a black box with the name of the power in it. I thought that this was kind of hokey. This anime contains excessive violence.

In the summer of 1945, Gen Nakaoka was just trying to get along in a world of rationing in WWII-era Japan. However, he was just your average kid, getting into mischief and enjoying life, mostly because his hometown - Hiroshima - was spared the near-constant bombings that plagued the rest of the islands.
However, everything changed on August 6, when Hiroshima was obliterated in the very first atomic bomb attack. Now with only his pregnant mother and brother with him, Gen has to find the strength and confidence to survive this new age which threatens his and his remaining family's existence.
These two movies were based on the manga by Kenji Nakazawa, which is a microcosm of what he had endured in the wake of the atomic bombings in Japan.

Barefoot Gen takes place near the end of World War II, when the U.S. and Japan are currently at odds. During the Summer of 1945, three years have passed since the war between the two countries began.
The story is about a 6-year old boy named Gen who lives in Hiroshima. Living in poverty, Gen's family is suffering from malnutrition. His father and pregnant mother struggle to make ends meet. However, history is about to make things much much worse for Gen's family. And their lives will change dramatically with the dropping of a bomb....
